At the tender age of 13, Angela made her stage debut in a production of "Gaslight" at the prestigious Old Vic Theatre in London.

The outbreak of World War II forced Angela to abandon her theatrical aspirations and take on war work. She joined the Civil Defense Corps and worked as a messenger, often traveling between government buildings and military installations. Despite the challenges of wartime, Angela continued to hone her craft, taking acting classes and participating in amateur dramatics.

After the war, Angela made the bold decision to leave her homeland and pursue a career in Hollywood. Her big break came when she landed a supporting role in the 1944 film "Gaslight," opposite Ingrid Bergman and Charles Boyer. Her performance caught the attention of Hollywood's elite, and soon she was in high demand.

Throughout the 1950s and 1960s, Angela established herself as a talented and versatile actress, appearing in a wide range of films, including "National Velvet," "The Manchurian Candidate," and "The Amorous Adventures of Moll Flanders." Her iconic portrayal of Sibyl Vane in the 1964 film "My Fair Lady" cemented her status as a Hollywood legend.

In the 1970s, Angela made the transition to television, starring in the beloved series "Murder, She Wrote" as the clever and charismatic amateur sleuth, Jessica Fletcher. The show ran for 12 seasons, earning Angela multiple Emmy nominations and a Peabody Award.

Throughout her illustrious career, Angela Lansbury has received numerous accolades, including three Academy Award nominations, five Golden Globe Awards, and a Tony Award for her work on Broadway.
